flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: This project is relatively easy; however, there are two things to consider before starting: Tube collection, and style. This project, the way I did it, used 224 standard toilet paper tubes (4 tiers). Depending on how much t.p. your household goes through in a week, and whether you collect from the neighbors, collecting this many tubes could take a short or very long time. It took me about 6 months before I had enough (I built it a little at a time, so I had this thing in the corner that slowly grew...), but that's because 1) I wasn't diligent enough and didn't collect every single tube that I could have, 2) I only accepted tubes that were perfect, no squashed or damp tubes, and 3) I didn't ask the neighbors, because they use a different brand of t.p. Speaking of which, the Style in which you do your crafts, affects tube collection a great deal. If I had collected all tubes from all possible sources, I probably would have completed the project within a month. However, I want the t.p.-tube-origin of this table to be a great clever secret, so I need it to be as perfect in appearance as possible, and as leveled and symmetrical as cardboard can be. I discovered that if you put tubes of different brands side by side, there will be up to a 1/4 inch difference in height. Since I wanted the parts of my table to be perfectly flat and make good contact with the glue, I stuck to just one brand of cardboard tubes. So again, you can be more or less precise with this project as you like. Just be aware that collecting 224 perfect tubes can take a Very Long Time!

guide.summary: Ever kept empty cardboard rolls around, hoping they might come in handy sometime? Here's the perfect thing! Tubes, cardboard, boxes, and paper are used to make a cute little nightstand table that looks great and is surprisingly sturdy and heavy.
guide.title: Sturdy Table from re-used Cardboard
